meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: Can I start with a question?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: As someone who doesn't think about bacteria, what do we know about the microbiome in terms of like AD and Parkinson's?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like the gut microbiome, like what do we know?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like are the similar bugs, not similar bugs?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Do you want to start with that, Ali?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sure.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh in fact, I give you a little bit of a story very quickly. I um had data on microbiota in Parkinson in 2011, 2012, which was markedly abnormal. And I was so fearful of whether there is a technical issue or not because no one was talking about it. And we put together to publish it and my uh colleague Dr. Mutlu uh was my fellow told me said by the way, do you know that uh we ran the samples for the Parkinson in one run and we ran the control the other run. And I said, should be okay, there is a control. He said, no, the uh the 16S has no internal control and for the first time I realized that the uh amplicon base and as we speak is still the case, there is no internal uh control. And run to run is significant. Uh and people don't talk about it. It's many things that we as a scientist we never shout Emperor doesn't have clothes till we find the alternative and they shout about it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well I hope I didn't publish it and that cost me two months delay that the group in um uh Finland published the same year 2015. Uh but the reason I mentioned that uh that you said is there a similarity between AD and Parkinson on microbiota?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: The difference in technique of interrogating microbiota and difference in collecting the stool, difference in extracting the DNA is so much that I don't think that you should uh consider that one to one even within the Parkinson, now the last time I checked there are 32 papers on Parkinson on microbiota all over the world and there is not a single uh signature that is identical.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: But you have a global view of it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: That Parkinson disease is one of the very, very few conditions that diversity is not decreased.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Before I had the Parkinson data, I thought that low diversity is just represent pathology.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I was flabbergasted that it is not the case and majority if not all the study in Parkinson shown there is no decrease diversity.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: In park in uh Alzheimer, some study shows that diversity is low. But it looks as if for neurodegenerative disease, diversity is not relevant. But as a whole for the Parkinson, you have relative, just remember that I said relative, unfortunately you are doing relative abundance. That means when you see that abundance of the taxa is down, it has to go some other taxa has to go up.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Now we are beginning to look at absolute because you are now measuring the total bacterial mass and we correct for it. But by and large is relative abundance of so-called pathobion.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Primarily in proteobacter group. And the relative abundance of so-called anti-inflammatory bacteria.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Primarily short chain fatty acid producing bacteria.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: But different studies have a different type of pathobion increase and different studies.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: A different uh type of short chain fatty acid producing bacteria that is decreased. Is a paper will coming out that I'm part of it from uh the German group.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: That they use the fancy bio statistics to harmonize over um I think 20 studies over thousand patient with Parkinson and he came up with the same conclusion.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And it appears that for MSA is the same.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: I've been published.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And is for Parkinson for um sorry, for Alzheimer is the same.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Therefore globe if you look at it in a very bird's eye view.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Which is a very crude way of looking at it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: They are similar.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: That as a whole.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: They have higher abundance of proinflammatory bacteria.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And lower abundance of uh anti-inflammatory bacteria primarily short chain fatty acid.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: But because of that issue.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Whether that there is no similarity, there is overlap, whether that lack of similarity because it's truly is different, which I believe that is the case or is a technique that is different.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Even in our lab, changing the pH or the temperature.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Of the run, we are going to get a different amplicon exaggeration.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: I don't know what Barbara think.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: But that is and the other one is the permeability.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh the increased permeability.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Is present in both diseases.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Now, I believe the permeability changes that is something after 30 odd years.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: That changes in regulation of the permeability which is very relevant because if you have a good barrier.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: No matter what happening in your gut, you have a better control of interaction of the gut bacteria to the circulation and in the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um that is either bacteria mediated loss of uh permeability or uh bacterial independent regulation of the permeability.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And many occasion they are overlap.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: And it appears in both Parkinson and um and Alzheimer.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh a combination of the both primarily the bacterial driven.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ali Keshavarzian
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh loss of permeability at least in animal.
